p: Before the 2009 influenza A(H1N1) pandemic, most countries in Africa had inadequate data on the burden of influenza disease and high risk groups to inform influenza public health policies [ 22]. Since then, influenza surveillance systems have been strengthened and many countries are studying influenza incidence and seasonality, particularly among sub-groups [ 1, 2]. Networks like ANISE [ 2] and AfriFlu [ 23] have increased the scientific dialogue among influenza experts in Africa.
